Award.AwardTitle: Scientific Integration and Coordination Activities of the International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme (IGBP), organized under the auspices of the International Council for Science recently completed a synthesis of its first decade of research and is embarking on its second decade with a broader, and even more integrative research agenda. The overall goal of this effort is to study interactions between biological, chemical and physical processes, and human systems. This effort will be conducted through eight core projects focused on the three major Earth System compartments (land, ocean and atmosphere), the three interfaces between these compartments, and two projects dealing with systems-level integration from the past through the present and into the future.

The IGBP will be coordinated by a scientific committee supported by the IGBP Secretariat. These coordination and integration activities will be aimed at facilitating the Earth System Science focus of the IGBP network by a) affecting efficient and comprehensive communication between the IGBP core projects and providing the Earth System context for the these projects; b) collaborating with its international partner programmes in the transdisciplinary Earth System Science Partnership to address wider issues of sustainability science and put IGBP results in the global change context; c) communicating the results of IGBP investigations into global environmental change in an understandable way to the wider scientific community, the education sector, agencies and other stakeholder organizations, and the public.

This integration will involve careful planning: identifying systems-level hypotheses and questions, constructing research infrastructure to address them, and ensuring that the efforts of the IGBP core projects are carried out in a synergistic manner. This will enable scientists from the natural and related social sciences and from more than eighty countries to collaborate in an efficient and focused manner to advance, not only their disciplinary fields, but, more importantly, address systems-level global environmental change issues. The IGBP will also continue to develop new ways of communicating the results of its research to stakeholders outside the science community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For over 20 years, the International Geosphere?Biosphere Programme (IGBP) has assembled overwhelming evidence of the unprecedented scale of changes to Earth's most important biological, chemical and physical, processes.

IGBP’s first synthesis resulted in the iconic publication, Global Change and the Earth System: a planet under pressure (Steffen et al 2004). This synthesis can be credited with the emergence and development of several landmark concepts in Earth-system research including the Anthropocene and planetary stewardship.   IGBP’s second synthesis of Earth-system research is now underway with a focus on the consequences of the Anthropocene for society as the guiding theme.

Informing the 2nd IGBP synthesis was IGBP’s Planetary Stewardship workshop, hosted at the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, 13-15 June 2011. The workshop brought together 30 leading experts from diverse disciplines to discuss an optimal approach to stewardship.

Research highlights in the lifetime of this grant:

  • 24 of the world’s 33 major deltas are sinking as a result of human activity. 500 million people live on deltas worldwide, according to researchers on the Land-Ocean Interaction in the Coastal Zone project.
  • The current rate of ocean acidification may be unprecedented in the last 300 million years according to researchers on the Past Global Changes project.
  • IGBP’s project that focuses on Earth system modelling has worked with partners to develop the next generation of emissions scenarios for the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).
  • A deeper understanding of the causes and consequences of land-use change was developed by integrating economic, social, and natural dimensions. 
  • IGBP and partners developed a summary for policymakers on ocean acidification outlining the main challenges and knowledge gaps.
  • The “State of the Arctic Coast 2010” report  provides a comprehensive picture of current and anticipated changes in the most sensitive Arctic coastal areas.
  • The global sulphur cycle holds particular interest to global-change scientists. One sulphur-containing molecule, dimethyl sulphide (DMS), has been under intense scrutiny for several decades. It is thought to affect cloud formation and so weather, climate and Earth’s radiation budget. IGBP’s ocean-atmosphere project has produced state-of-the-art global maps showing monthly distribution of DMS.

IGBP has formidable international convening power. A highlight of our efforts during the past year was the recent Planet Under Pressure conference (London, March 2012). The conference, which we sponsored in partnership with other global-environmental-change programmes, brought together 3000 researchers, policymakers, development practitioners, media and industry. A further 3000 joined online making it the largest gathering of its kind. The conference brought together a new community that will form the nucleus for the new Future Earth initiative being developed by the International Council for Science, major funding agencies and partners. It marked a turning point in our research focus towards global sustainability research with an emphasis on solutions. 

IGBP continues to actively engage with the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and make contributions in support of the Fifth Assessment Report. IGBP holds joint workshops with IPCC and the research it coordinates leads to high-profile peer-reviewed publications on a range of climate relevant topics.  Over 70 scientists from the IGBP research community were selected by the IPCC as authors and review editors for the Fifth Assessment Report.
